abstract.p: Article describes new Kodak Advantix Preview camera; photo (M)

block.p: With its smart, ergonomic styling and color L.C.D. screen in a button-studded back panel, the new Kodak Advantix Preview camera looks like another point-and-shoot that has gone thoroughly digital.

With its smart, ergonomic styling and color L.C.D. screen in a button-studded back panel, the new Kodak Advantix Preview camera looks like another point-and-shoot that has gone thoroughly digital.
Despite its advanced circuitry and chip sets inside, this $300 Kodak camera has not embraced megapixels. Instead it is still wedded to film. So why all the electronics?
Kodak designers said they listened to consumers and learned that many of them still preferred film but would like greater control over which pictures are actually printed.

Using a CCD image sensor, the same device that is at the heart of most digital cameras, the Preview camera takes two pictures: one that is exposed on Advantix film and another electronic one that is displayed on a preview window on the back of the camera. If a photographer doesn't like the picture, which is rendered to closely match what is captured on film, he or she can easily set a selector to tell the photo finisher to skip that shot.
The same selector can also adjust the setting on any picture to have as many as nine copies of it made when the film is developed.
The camera, which has a 2.6x zoom lens and a six-function built-in flash, also has other controls to change the format of the picture.
